page.title: 11New Tean Mill
page.content: The brick building which dominates Tean High Street has been called the best example of its kind in the country.At the East end is a black and white Hall dated 1613 which was taken over by the Philips family(see Heath House) when they brought the weaving industry to the area in about 1750. At first the Hall was the administrative centre only,with the spinning and weaving being done in the workers' cottages. Some of these cottages, although no longer used as work places,were in existence until 1966.When they were in use the family lived downstairs and the workrooms were upstairs.The company started to expand the High Street Building westwards and in the 1820's steam driven looms were introduced, thus greatly reducing the work force but increasing output.
